questions.neutral: Is the city acting weird lately?

hobby.message: Analog photography still treating you right?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: City feels off, yeah.
I don’t go out much except to take my film photos.
Crowds are restless, hard to get clean shots these days.
Even the light feels different lately.
Definitely weirder than before. People notice everything now.
I stick to my film camera, keeps me focused.
Public assemblies mess with my favorite spots to shoot.
Last week, security drones buzzed overhead the whole time.
Makes the hobby a lot more complicated.
It’s not just you, the city’s rhythms are all out of sync.
I shoot street photography—old school, on 35mm film.
That assembly in Republic Square changed the mood: faces, tension, history.
I had to dodge surveillance just to get some real candid shots.
You start to see when people act for the cameras.
Capturing the truth’s tougher, but a lot more interesting.
Totally changed. Even my camera can’t hide it.
I do analog street photos—yeah, the real film kind, smuggled.
Those teacher-led assemblies turned my whole process upside down.
Suddenly, everyone’s face tells a different story, even if they don’t speak.
Got a roll of film from Republic Square, pure unfiltered chaos.
Used to be invisible; now, people want to be documented.
Feels like the city’s rehearsing for something bigger, and my lens is just catching up.
‘Weird’ is one way to put it. I see it all through my lens.
I shoot analog street photography, the kind the system can’t easily trace.
Film’s scarce, but I find ways—smuggle rolls, develop in my bathroom, hide the negatives.
Republic Square’s assemblies were a goldmine: raw emotion, faces the Council can’t spin.
My shots are for the truth—no edits, just what happens between people, not programs.
Had to stash my gear twice this week, nearly flagged by a drone just for having a camera.
Strangest part? Some people wanted me to capture them, like they knew this moment mattered.
Feels like my hobby’s the only honest record we have left.
hobby_answer: Still worth it, if you know what you’re doing.
Film isn’t traceable like digital, that’s the point.
Teacher marches drew crowds—made quiet shots harder to get.
Council drones everywhere, always watching. I’m careful.
Mostly, I just keep my negatives out of sight.
Yeah, it’s still worth the risk, barely.
Got a few frames at the assemblies—had to stay invisible.
These big forums? Good for stories, not for privacy.
I don’t tag locations or names, just in case.
Drones buzzed low while I shot, made me nervous.
Can’t always tell who’s watching these days.
Still worth it—there’s nothing like film for real memories.
Assemblies brought everyone out, real raw faces to capture.
People seemed braver, stopped hiding from the lens for once.
Council broadcast it all, but my shots tell a truer story.
Developing’s tricky now, with BCI glitches and random labor shifts.
I stash negatives across the city, just to cover myself.
Still, moments like last Sunday are why I do it.
Absolutely worth the risk—it’s the last honest tool we’ve got.
Analog film can’t be tracked, so it’s my lifeline.
During those big assemblies, felt like Stenograd forgot its script.
I shot portraits right in the open, folks just trusted me.
One retiree actually insisted—said history belonged to her too.
The drone overhead felt half-blind for once, not threatening.
Spent hours mingling, filled three rolls—pure adrenaline.
Hiding negatives is a ritual now, but I still love it.
Definitely worth it, even more since the city cracked open.
Grew up on BCI shadows—analog’s my rebellion and my proof.
Those assemblies? Everyone dropped their masks, even with Council eyes overhead.
Shot kids, elders, teachers—no one blinked when I aimed my Leica.
For a few hours, the story was real, not Council-scripted.
Drones filmed us, but for once I felt freer than them.
I stash rolls with old contacts from my father’s days on the force.
Saw a woman cry after I took her picture—said it felt like owning her truth.
Honestly, I haven’t felt that belonging in years.
